conclusion: We need to determine the time taken for the small ball to move from point B to point C using the properties of projectile motion and the geometry of the semicylinder.
The semicylinder has a radius R = 0.75 m, and the angle between OC and the horizontal direction is 53°. Point B is directly above point A, and the ball grazes past point C on the semicylinder.
The vertical distance from C to the horizontal is R sin 53°, and the horizontal distance is R cos 53°.
The vertical distance traveled by the ball is R, as the ball starts at point B and ends at point C.
Using the kinematic equation for vertical motion, the vertical displacement is -R, the initial vertical velocity is 0, and the equation becomes -R = 0 - (1/2) g t^2.
Solving the equation -R = - (1/2) g t^2 gives t^2 = 2R / g, and t = sqrt(2R / g).
Substituting R = 0.75 m and g = 10 m/s², t = sqrt(2 × 0.75 / 10) = sqrt(0.15) = sqrt(3/20) = sqrt(15)/10 seconds.
The horizontal distance traveled by the ball is R cos 53°, which equals 0.75 × 0.6 = 0.45 m.
The horizontal component of the velocity is v_x = R cos 53° / t = 0.45 / (sqrt(15)/10) = (0.45 × 10) / sqrt(15) = 4.5 / sqrt(15) = (4.5 sqrt(15)) / 15 = sqrt(15)/3 m/s.
The horizontal component of the velocity is not needed to find the time, as it has already been determined from the vertical motion.
The time taken for the small ball to move from point B to point C is sqrt(15)/10 seconds.
